engine.rendering

Class Bitmap

  • java.lang.Object
    • engine.rendering.Bitmap
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    RenderContext

    public class Bitmap
extends java.lang.Object
    Stores a set of pixels in a component-based format. The component-based format stores colors as follows:

    Byte 0: Alpha
    Byte 1: Blue
    Byte 2: Green
    Byte 3: Red

    This format is fast, compact, and ideal for software rendering. It has the following key advantages:

    - Entire images can be copied to the screen with a single call to System.arrayCopy. (If the screen is not in ABGR pixel format, it requires some conversion. However, the conversion is typically quick and simple).
    - Per component operations, such as lighting, can be performed cheaply without any pixel format conversion.

    This class is primarily intended to be a high-performance image storing facility for software rendering. As such, there are points where ease of use is compromised for the sake of performance. If you need to store and use images outside of a software renderer, it is recommended that you use Java's standard image classes instead.

    Author:
    Benny Bobaganoosh (thebennybox@gmail.com)

    • Constructor Detail

      • Bitmap

        public Bitmap(int width,
      int height)
        Creates and initializes a Bitmap.
        Parameters:
        width - The width, in pixels, of the image.
        height - The height, in pixels, of the image.

      • Bitmap

        public Bitmap(java.lang.String fileName)
       throws java.io.IOException
        Loads an image into a Bitmap from a file.
        Parameters:
        fileName - The name of the file to be loaded. File paths are relative to the resource folder, so a file in "C:/myFolder/myProject/projectResourceFolder/textures/myImage.png" should be specified as "textures/myImage.png"
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

    • Method Detail

      • getNewDefaultBitmap

        public static Bitmap getNewDefaultBitmap()
        Generates a Bitmap with a checkerboard pattern.

        This will generate a new bitmap every call. This is intended to prevent issues with modifying part of the default Bitmap, and having that affect other users of default bitmaps.

        Note that this method is intended primarily for debugging usage.

        Returns:
        Bitmap with checkerboard pattern.

      • clear

        public void clear(byte shade)
        Sets every pixel in the bitmap to a specific shade of grey.
        Parameters:
        shade - The shade of grey to use, where (byte)0x00 is black, and (byte)0xFF is white.

      • drawPixel

        public void drawPixel(int x,
             int y,
             byte a,
             byte b,
             byte g,
             byte r)
        Sets the pixel at (x, y) to the color specified by (a,b,g,r).
        Parameters:
        x - The x location in the bitmap to change.
        y - The y location in the bitmap to change.
        a - The alpha value of the desired color.
        b - The blue value of the desired color.
        g - The green value of the desired color.
        r - The red value of the desired color.

      • copyToByteArray

        public void copyToByteArray(byte[] dest)
        Copies the Bitmap into a BGR byte array.
        Parameters:
        dest - The byte array to be copied into. This array is assumed to be large enough to hold the bitmap.

      • copyNearest

        public void copyNearest(Bitmap dest,
               int destX,
               int destY,
               float srcXFloat,
               float srcYFloat)
        Copies the pixel nearest to the normalized coordinates (srcXFloat, srcYFloat) into the dest Bitmap at location (destX, destY).
        Parameters:
        dest - The Bitmap being copied into.
        destX - The location of the destination pixel in X.
        destY - The location of the destination pixel in Y.
        srcXFloat - The location of the pixel being copied on X, normalized into the range (0, 1)
        srcYFloat - The location of the pixel being copied on Y, normalized into the range (0, 1)

      • clearScreen

        public Bitmap clearScreen(byte a,
                 byte b,
                 byte g,
                 byte r)
        Sets every pixel in the Bitmap to a specific color.
        Parameters:
        a - The alpha value of the desired color.
        b - The blue value of the desired color.
        g - The green value of the desired color.
        r - The red value of the desired color.
        Returns:
        This Bitmap, for programming convenience.

        public byte getComponent(int location)
